<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 418, 230, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 435, 808, 574]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- You may use a calculator.- You should show all your working and use appropriate units.- Take the weight of \(1.0 \text{kg}\) to be \(10 \text{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10 \text{m/s}^2\)).  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 603, 220, 618]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 619, 730, 651]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 80.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[285, 867, 712, 883]]<|/det|>
This document has 16 pages. Blank pages are indicated.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
An aeroplane of mass \(2.5 \times 10^{5} \text{kg}\) lands with a speed of \(62 \text{m/s}\), on a horizontal runway at time \(t = 0\). The aeroplane decelerates uniformly as it travels along the runway in a straight line until it reaches a speed of \(6.0 \text{m/s}\) at \(t = 35 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 134, 144, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 134, 243, 152]]<|/det|>
Calculate:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 164, 180, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 164, 663, 183]]<|/det|>
the deceleration of the aeroplane in the \(35 \text{s}\) after it lands

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 241, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>deceleration = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 272, 180, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 687, 291]]<|/det|>
the resultant force acting on the aeroplane as it decelerates

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[520, 350, 920, 368]]<|/det|>
<form>force = .......................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[144, 381, 180, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(iii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 381, 680, 400]]<|/det|>
the momentum of the aeroplane when its speed is \(6.0 \text{m/s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 459, 920, 477]]<|/det|>
<form>momentum = .................................................... [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 490, 146, 508]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 920, 523]]<|/det|>
At \(t = 35 \text{s}\), the aeroplane stops decelerating and moves along the runway at a constant speed of \(6.0 \text{m/s}\) for a further \(15 \text{s}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 536, 920, 570]]<|/det|>
On Fig. 1.1, sketch the shape of the graph for the distance travelled by the aeroplane along the runway between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 50 \text{s}\). You are **not** required to calculate distance values.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 120]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 715, 91]]<|/det|>
Fig. 3.1 shows gas trapped in the sealed end of a tube by a dense liquid.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 108, 740, 425]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 433, 532, 452]]<|/det|>
<label>Fig. 3.1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 464, 920, 498]]<|/det|>
The scale marked on the sealed end of the tube is calibrated to read the volume of gas trapped above the liquid surface. Fig. 3.1 shows that initially the volume \(V_{1}\) of the gas is \(60 \text{cm}^3\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 510, 514, 528]]<|/det|>
The pressure of the atmosphere is \(1.0 \times 10^{5} \text{Pa}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 542, 144, 560]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 541, 920, 575]]<|/det|>
State how Fig. 3.1 shows that the pressure of the trapped gas is equal to the pressure of the atmosphere.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 618, 920, 637]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 650, 146, 668]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 650, 920, 683]]<|/det|>
Explain, in terms of the momentum of its molecules, why the trapped gas exerts a pressure on the walls of the tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[880, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 73, 146, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
More of the dense liquid is poured into the open end of the tube. The level of the liquid surface in both the sealed and the open ends of the tube rises as shown in Fig. 3.2. The temperature of the trapped gas and atmospheric pressure both remain constant.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[252, 128, 740, 437]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>image_caption<|/ref|><|det|>[[463, 448, 534, 467]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 479, 181, 498]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 477, 920, 512]]<|/det|>
In the sealed end of the tube, the volume \(V_{2}\) of the trapped gas is \(50 \text{cm}^3\). In the open end of the tube, the liquid surface is \(15 \text{cm}\) above the new level in the sealed tube.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 526, 566, 545]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
The power supply used in an electric vehicle contains 990 rechargeable cells each of electromotive force (e.m.f.) 1.2V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 920, 152]]<|/det|>
The cells are contained in packs in which all the cells are in series with each other. The e.m.f. of each pack is 54 V.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 165, 146, 183]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>
